audio_caption: The audio clip starts with energetic rock music, creating an upbeat atmosphere. A male voice announces "Taylor Schilling everybody, Taylor Schilling!" with an excited tone. The music fades slightly as the announcer continues speaking, followed by a female voice in a surprised and excited tone exclaiming, "Oh my god!". A male voice adds "Yeah! Hello Taylor, you look sensational!". The female voice responds again, "Oh my gosh, so do you". Someone else, presumably male, exclaims "Oh stop!". The first male speaker talks about how everyone will stand up, and also that many of them have been in prison, and how excited they are. The music continues faintly in the background throughout the exchange.

The scene begins with a conversational exchange between a man and a woman who seems excited and thankful to be on the show. The man responds jokingly, then the woman expresses confusion about a horse. A male voice reacts to what the horse is doing. Another male voice responds, also jokingly. The first woman comments on the weirdness of the horse being there. The man responds, noting the horse would not be as weird as an empty stable. The woman notes she likes horses, and the man responds that the horse is not weird but the gay robot skeleton is not. The first woman comments on what the man says. The male voice jokes about excitement to see the first female. The woman jokes about it as well, and a male voice requests to do it again, with some excitement. There is then audience applause. The first man says it sounds great, and that he is glad. The man replies, "Alright, alright. Talk to daddy now." with laughter. Then there is a male voice, and he says he will let her do it. There is laughter from both speakers. Then the man says it is fine and the woman asks if the man lives in Manhattan or Brooklyn.

The audio clip features two speakers, a man and a woman. The man presumes the woman lives in Brooklyn. The woman, speaking in an upbeat tone, corrects him, stating that she doesn't, but acknowledges that "Brooklyn is very cool". She then explains that she lives in Manhattan because it's "quicker" and "easier to get to work that way". Her tone is casual and conversational. There are no apparent background sounds or music.

The clip begins with a male speaker, who has a slight accent, inquiring "You met me in Manhattan?" Another female voice replies, "You met me in Queens." The male speaker acknowledges Queens, saying he's been there. There's a short burst of laughter from an audience, suggesting a live setting. The female speaker says, "I bet you had-" then gets cut off by the male speaker stating he used to live in Manhattan and asks if she has lived there her whole life. The woman replies she has lived there since she was eighteen. He said he moved there when he was a little older than that, which prompts her to ask how old he was. He states, "About twenty." There is audience laughter at his response. She agrees it's a fun place to live when you're twenty. He agrees, it is kind of "Yeah". The female speaker replies, "I bet".

The audio clip begins with two speakers, a man and a woman, engaged in conversation. The man suggests the woman, an actress, is busy and should avoid late nights. The woman makes a joking "No!" noise in response. The man playfully urges her on, noting that she works constantly on shows. She confirms she works a lot, wearing orange. The woman mentions she must get ready for work, putting on a jumpsuit and having her makeup removed. She clarifies she's not allowed to wear makeup on set, implying she dressed up for the current occasion. The man compliments her appearance. She acknowledges the situation. A musical interlude begins, a playful and silly rendition featuring what sounds like a slide whistle, creating an humorous mood. The woman jokes her torso is moving again. The man humorously threatens to close the top half of a door if she doesn't behave, concluding with a brief moment of laughter.

The clip starts with a question from a male speaker, inquiring "Do you ever ride horses?". A female speaker replies in an enthusiastic tone that she does, though not in Manhattan, as she jokes "that would hurt the horses". The male speaker, in a conversational tone, suggests riding in Central Park could be alright, but the female speaker counters that "something would get hurt", such as the horse or a pedestrian. The male speaker expresses surprised disbelief, leading into a question of "How do you ride horses?" and he characterizes her as sounding like a "mad woman". Finally, he asks whether she rides horses fast, and she explains that one can gallop if wanted, but the male speaker interrupts that he already knows this, and she interjects that she rides them in New Jersey.

The clip begins with a casual spoken agreement with an uncertain tone, then quickly shifts to an amused sigh. Following this, a male voice inquires about a problem, with a female speaker answering by saying "I'm just taking it all in", indicating a sense of overwhelm. She further explains that this is her first show, with the male speaker responding that there aren't many shows like this. She comments on the lack of 'Jeff', with the male speaker clarifying that they don't have 'Jeff' or a horse, but rather proper things. He then asks if they get along on their show, with a female speaker responding in the affirmative and the male speaker mocking the idea that "everybody in Hollywood gets along." A brief moment of laughter follows.

The clip starts with a conversational tone from a man who says "can't all get along?". A woman responds, stating "The ones that I work with, we do", emphasizing that she doesn't see many people in the cast but those she does work with are "amazing". The man then says they are "really good actresses", but the woman corrects him, saying "amazing". The man clarifies, "there's actors in it too". The woman acknowledges this with "there are too" and repeats that she doesn't see many of them.

The audio clip starts with a female speaker mentioning "Jason Banks," followed by a male speaker agreeing that he's funny, describing him as "really funny" and "very hairy." The male speaker then elaborates on hugging Jason, saying that "you can hear it crinkle," likening the sound to rustling a newspaper, but describing him as a "lovely guy though." The female speaker agrees, and the male speaker jokes he always has to resist giving Jason a banana. Laughter from both speakers follows. The male speaker declares "Well, we're out of time" before the female speaker, with a sigh, agrees he is "wonderful." The male speaker, sounding slightly aggrieved, asks if the other speaker is ignoring him, and the female speaker replies she didn't even hear him. She explains she could only hear his "pipe and your teeth."

The audio clip starts with a male speaker enthusiastically mentioning, "Oh, you know what I got?" He excitedly introduces a water pick, emphasizing its high-pressure cleaning action and humorously notes that it "sandblasts your teeth." The audience responds with laughter, then he jokingly shares he "got haggis from 1974" coming out. This is followed by laughter and applause. The speaker reacts with surprise, asking, "Why would you applaud that?" He and a female speaker acknowledge soft applause, both expressing confusion regarding the audience's reaction and noting that the applause is strange.

The audio clip begins with two speakers, a male and a female. The male speaker comments on the audience, joking they "all been busted in from the women's prison." The female speaker responds affirmatively, "They're my people." The male suggests she can "have them." Then, a sound resembling a whoop is heard, presumably from the audience. The male speaker acknowledges the passing of time, indicating "we're out of time, like I said," before proposing options such as "an awkward pause" or to "twerk with the horse."

The audio clip starts with a female voice requesting, "I'd like to see you twerk with the horse." A male voice responds with a slightly mocking, "Yeah, I bet you would." This is followed by loud cheering from an audience. The male speaker continues, explaining that he already "twerks with a horse every damn night" and that the requester has clearly never seen the show. He then states he cannot do it tonight. The female speaker then responds, agreeing and stating that she understands.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker giving a question: "Do you want to do that or... just have an awkward pause?". He then offers alternatives such as "Want to have a mouth organ?" The female speaker asks back, "What's a mouth organ?" There is some quiet audience laughter. The male speaker follows up: "One of these... Harmonica." The female speaker states that she does not know how to play, but recognizes it as "like Bob Dylan." The male speaker responds that it's "more metallic than Bob Dylan", but suggests that she could try playing it. The female speaker asks the male to "play a little bit of a..." There is the distinct sound of a harmonica, played well.

The audio clip starts with a woman speaking, mentioning something about a train arriving. She sounds surprised. A man responds, commenting on the woman's statement. She agrees and then requests that the man play something. The man agrees, and an air horn sound is heard. Applause follows, accompanied by music that sounds like a children's song. The music features a synthesized brass instrument and is cheerful in tone.
